rename.from: Temporary file is deleted before returning a response
rename.to: Temporary file is deleted before a controller returns a response

body:
Actually this code is working as intended. The "problem" you run into is that after retrieving the `path` of `image.ref` you do not access `image.ref` anymore, so there is no need for the JVM to keep a reference to the object if points to and "releases" the object it points to for garbage collection. When the object gets "destroyed" it will also remove its temporary file, you can see that here:
https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/814d1921b1f8eb7a743db5f93178b49b26fd8232/core/play/src/main/scala/play/api/libs/Files.scala#L281-L286
Because you force garbage collection and afterwards access the `path`, the file `path` represents is already deleted.
I see you added a `sleep` statement to make sure Garbage collection finished before you call `Files.size` on the temp file. Without the `sleep` statement sometimes the code works, sometimes it fails. Depending if Garbage collection is fast enough to delete the file or not.
Now, for me this is not a bug, but just how this is designed to work. So you have to understand as soon you do not reference `image.ref` anymore you can not be sure that the file it represents on the file system still exists afterwards. So IMHO you have two choices:
1. Either move the temporary file to a different location so it will not be deleted when the `image.ref` gets destroyed and then only work with that "new" file, e.g.:
    ```scala
        case Some(image) =>
          for {
            path <- Future(image.ref.atomicMoveWithFallback(someTargetPath))
            ...
    ```
    Be aware that `someTargetPath`/`path` will not be deleted automatically anymore, it's managed by you and you have to make sure to remove it or do whatever you want with it.
1. Do not save a reference to `image.ref.path`. If you do not access `image.ref` anymore it means the file it references is never safe to access. In your code you could do following instead:
    ```scala
          for {
            fsize <- Future(Files.size(image.ref.path))
            _ <- Future(System.gc())
            _ <- Future(Thread.sleep(100))
          } yield Ok(fsize.toString)
    ```

- [ ] We might want to be more clear about how things work in the documentation:
https://www.playframework.com/documentation/3.0.x/ScalaFileUpload#Cleaning-up-temporary-files

- [ ] Also actually your example makes a good (scripted?) test to make sure that temporary files get deleted when the `ref` object gets destroyed (not sure how intense we test this yet).

Thank you for your response.

I understand the mechanism, but I feel that not retaining the reference to `image.ref.path` in 2. makes it prone to programming errors and difficult to handle.

As a third option, it seems possible to retain the reference to the request until the end. By retaining the reference to the request, the reference to the TemporaryFile is also retained, so the file will not be deleted.

```scala
  def fileSize() =
    Action.async(parse.multipartFormData) { implicit request =>
      request.body.file("file") match {
        case Some(image) =>
          for {
            path <- Future(image.ref.path)
            _ <- Future(System.gc())
            _ <- Future(Thread.sleep(100))
          } yield Ok{
            request // just for retaining a reference
            Files.size(path).toString
          }
        case None =>
          Future.successful(BadRequest("No image supplied"))
      }
    }
```

Is it possible to implement this on the framework side? Like changing

https://github.com/playframework/playframework/blob/814d1921b1f8eb7a743db5f93178b49b26fd8232/core/play/src/main/scala/play/api/mvc/Action.scala#L434

to following? (Behavior has not been confirmed.)

```
invokeBlock(request, block).andThen(_ => request)
```

Regarding 1., I am a bit concerned about the extra I/O that occurs.

That's an interesting idea. Actually yesterday I tried
```scala
...
            _ <- Future(Thread.sleep(100))
            _ <- Future(image.ref) // <--
          } yield Ok(Files.size(path).toString)
...
```
to keep the object alive, which also worked, but haven't thought about to keep a reference to request within Play itself.
Your solution makes sense. Could you open a pull request? Would be nice if you could add a test also. fyi, afaik `System.gc()` does not guarantee that GC will actually be triggered, it just asks the JVM to do so. So _in theory_ such a test is not 100% reliable, but I guess since we can both reproduce the exception, you with corretto on macOS and me with Temurin on Linux, _in practise_ we can say it's safe to assume `System.gc()` does what we want for such a test.

issue.title: Prevent TemporaryFile to be deleted before returning a response

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
<!--- Copyright (C) from 2022 The Play Framework Contributors <https://github.com/playframework>, 2011-2021 Lightbend Inc. <https://www.lightbend.com> -->

# Pull Request Checklist

* [x] Have you read [How to write the perfect pull request](https://github.blog/2015-01-21-how-to-write-the-perfect-pull-request/)?
* [x] Have you read through the [contributor guidelines](https://www.playframework.com/contributing)?
* [x] Have you referenced any issues you're fixing using [commit message keywords](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue)?
* [ ] Have you added copyright headers to new files?
* [ ] Have you checked that both Scala and Java APIs are updated?
* [ ] Have you updated the documentation for both Scala and Java sections?
* [x] Have you added tests for any changed functionality?

# Helpful things

## Fixes

Fixes #12770

## Purpose

If the Path of a temporary file is retrieved and processed, the TemporaryFile may be deleted before the response is finished (#12770). This pull request will prevent TemporaryFile from being deleted until the response is finished.


cc/ @mkurz

body: @tkawachi Play 3.0.5 with the fix was just released.

Hi @mkurz 
I guess I encountered the same issue on Play 2.6.1, so I'm curious if you fixed it in the previous version or I need to find another way out?
@weichengliao11 This is only fixed in latest Play 2.9.x and 3.0.x releases. All previous Play releases are not supported anymore.
